question_text: What do details in paragraphs 1 through 5 suggest about Amy and Todd?
options: Todd has different interests than Amy does.
Todd is more focused on school than Amy is.
Todd is more interested in watching TV than Amy is.
Todd has a different reaction to his mother's voice than Amy does.

question_text: What does the word "straggled" in paragraph 5 suggest about Todd, Amy, and their father?
options: They are trying to keep the mother from seeing the kitchen.
They are determined to finish the work in the kitchen.
They want to keep close together in the kitchen.
They want to avoid going into the kitchen.

question_text: Why does Todd and Amy's father refuse to look at the Sixty-Minute Gourmet cookbook?
options: He thinks that they do not have the skills to make the recipes.
He knows the family does not have the right ingredients.
He knows that the recipes will take too long to make.
He thinks that the mother will dislike the meal.

question_text: The narrator's description of the conversation in paragraphs 11 through 13 shows that
options: the family has different ideas about a balanced diet
Amy knows which foods her mother likes best
Todd has experience with cooking
the father relies on his children's knowledge

question_text: The illustration best supports the information provided in which paragraph?
options: paragraph 12
paragraph 13
paragraph 24
paragraph 27

question_text: How does paragraph 28 relate to paragraph 8?
options: Paragraph 28 provides further details about the problem.
Paragraph 28 shows the result of the mother's instructions.
Paragraph 28 presents a summary of the tasks that are introduced.
Paragraph 28 explains how the meal is unlike the mother's request.

question_text: Which theme is supported by the events in the story?
options: Solving problems becomes easier with daily practice.
Challenges can give people opportunities for learning.
Doing work can help people forget their problems.
Feelings of guilt may go away over time.

question_text: How do paragraphs 1 through 4 support a main idea of the article?
options: by describing how well Clara did at school
by showing how Clara's parents made decisions
by showing Clara's behavior around other people
by providing details about Clara's cousins

question_text: Why did Clara return from boarding school?
options: The people who cared for Clara were concerned about her health.
Clara was younger and smaller than most of the other students.
The teachers thought Clara could learn more at home.
Clara was unhappy because she missed her family.

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 5.
'But it was a little late to rein Clara in now.'
What does the phrase "to rein Clara in" suggest?
options: Clara was too old to play with her cousins.
Clara was often outside after dark.
Clara was determined to learn new things in the country.
Clara was unable to ride horses.

question_text: What do paragraphs 5 and 6 show about Clara?
options: Clara is active and adventurous.
Clara is obedient and intelligent.
Clara is quiet and cooperative.
Clara is creative and serious.

question_text: Why is paragraph 9 important for the article?
options: It explains why Clara was a good caretaker to her brother.
It shows a result of Clara's caretaking skills.
It suggests why Clara's great aunt inspired her.
It connects Clara and her desire to care for people to her great aunt.

question_text: How did Clara's relationship with her brother David most affect her life?
options: By doing chores for David, Clara realized she enjoyed living at home.
By caring for David when he was injured, Clara developed a desire to help others.
By giving David his medicine, Clara learned about effective medical treatments.
By being home when David fell to the ground, Clara felt responsible for his injuries.

question_text: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the article?
options: Clara learned how to ride horses at a young age.
Clara had a great aunt who was a skilled midwife.
Clara was seriously hurt while ice skating with her cousins.
Clara remembered how good it felt to care for her brother.

question_text: What does "take it up a notch" mean as it is used in paragraph 4?
options: to make more interesting
to become more forceful
to complete another level
to make another play

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 7.
'That candor might be hard for the members of the girls' basketball team at John Marshall Metropolitan High School to hear.'
What idea does this sentence help to support?
options: that Gaters can be considered impolite
that Gaters speaks very softly at times
that Gaters demands a lot from her players
that Gaters is impatient with her players

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 7.
'They know this is a woman who can take them places.'
How does the author best support this point?
options: by explaining how Gaters helps many of her players attend college
by describing the long hours of practice Gaters makes her players perform
by providing examples of how Gaters helps players in need
by providing examples of the basketball tips Gaters teaches her players

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 21.
'But though Gaters is tough, it is a tough love, her former players say.'
Which point in the article does this detail best support?
options: Gaters has a very strong desire to win so can get upset easily.
Gaters is unlikely to retire because she enjoys coaching.
Gaters cares about every aspect of her players' lives.
Gaters is nice only after practice or games are finished.

question_text: What does paragraph 26 suggest about Gaters?
options: Gaters is appreciated for her important contributions to girls basketball.
Gaters is considered the best high school basketball coach in the country.
Gaters has coached basketball almost as long as more famous coaches.
Gaters has been honored mainly for her work with students off the basketball court.

question_text: How do paragraphs 27 through 29 contribute to the article?
options: by comparing Gaters's work ethic with Howard's
by showing an effect Gaters has had on Howard
by giving an example of Gaters's desire to win
by suggesting how Gaters feels about her job

question_text: According to the article, why do so many people respect Gaters?
options: Gaters teaches her players about more than just basketball.
Gaters encourages her players to play college basketball.
Gaters teaches her players about the importance of playing basketball.
Gaters wants her players to concentrate on improving their basketball skills.

question_text: What does the simile "like an earthquake" in paragraph 5 help the reader understand?
options: that volume can strongly affect parts of the ear
that hair cells are easily damaged
how our body is unable to re-grow hair cells
how much damage the ear can take

question_text: How do paragraphs 4 and 5 connect to paragraph 6?
options: Paragraphs 4 and 5 explain how hearing loss can occur, and paragraph 6 explains how to prevent it.
Paragraphs 4 and 5 show what damage can occur, and paragraph 6 shows how it affects people.
Paragraphs 4 and 5 describe how the ear can be damaged, and paragraph 6 describes how people react to the damage.
Paragraphs 4 and 5 explain why ears get damaged, and paragraph 6 explains why protecting hearing is important.

question_text: Which evidence best supports a claim made by the author in paragraph 4?
options: "If others can hear your music, the volume is too high." (paragraph 6)
"Yahaira admits that sometimes after listening to loud music, her ears make a ringing sound." (paragraph 7)
"So we need to protect that very special sense." (paragraph 8)
"Music companies have been deliberately turning up the volume." (paragraph 9)

question_text: According to paragraphs 9 through 12, how is the music business today different from the business in the 1980s or 1990s?
options: Today's music companies control the volume of music more than in the past.
Today's music companies compete against each other more than in the past.
Today's listeners of music like their music louder than they did in the past.
Today's sound engineers make music sound clearer than it did in the past.

question_text: Which paragraph best explains how loud noises can damage our hearing?
options: paragraph 1
paragraph 5
paragraph 7
paragraph 13

question_text: Which information explained in paragraph 13 does the drawing help the reader understand?
options: the shape of the parts of the ear
the position of the parts of the ear
the order in which sound waves strike the parts of the ear
the size of sound waves when moving through the parts of the ear

question_text: Which idea is most important to include in a summary of the article?
options: Music is not as powerful when played at quiet volumes.
Powerful instruments cause most hearing loss.
Choosing to play music quietly can protect hearing.
Music companies determine safe volume levels.

How did the home of the President change from 1800 through 1814? Use two details from the article to support your response.

What is a main idea of the article "Excerpt from Baby Mammoth Mummy: Frozen in Time!"? Use two details from the article to support your response.
